awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mantle metasomatism during serpentinization in subduction zones: Insights from in-situ boron isotopes
awd_abstract_narration:
Subduction zones are regions of our planet where tectonic plates converge. These regions are among the most geologically active on Earth, expressed by high rates of volcanism and seismicity (e.g., the Pacific Ring of Fire). They are ubiquitous features on Earth and represent the most extensive element recycling system between the interior and exterior of our planet. The processes occurring in subduction zones involve an enormous amount of fluids from different sources, which change the chemistry and alter the composition of the surrounding rocks from the surface to depths of ~100 km. The present project aims to better constrain the source(s) and paths of these fluids, as well as their role on subduction zone processes such as rock-fluid interaction and volcanism. This project will be carried out by faculty that belong to underrepresented groups in geosciences as well as impact students from a minority-serving institution in the NYC area.

Serpentine forms by alteration of the mantle by aqueous fluids and contains up to 14 wt. % of water, making it one of the most important records of fluid-rock interactions in subduction zone processes. Therefore, it represents a critical mineral to study the source and role of aqueous fluids within convergent plate boundaries. Recent studies based on boron (a fluid mobile element) suggest that serpentinites found in suture zones record processes that occurred mainly in: (i) the subducting slab, (ii) the mantle wedge, (iii) the hydrated forearc. Thus, serpentinites in suture zones represent the largest trackable record of aqueous fluids responsible for mantle metasomatism from different sources. Although the two main fluid endmembers in terms of B isotopes (seawater and high-pressure metamorphic fluids) are well-characterized, little is known about how these fluids mix, overprint, and evolve with the changes in P and T during subduction. The main goal of this study is to characterize fluid mixing/overprinting and secondary processes occurring in serpentinites collected in suture zones, using B isotopes and B contents. Our study will provide a better picture of the dehydration/(re)hydration processes occurring during subduction. Additionally, these data are necessary to understand the role of fluid(s) in triggering deep earthquakes and better constrain the fluid(s) responsible for mantle melting in subduction zones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to petrologically characterize and collect boron isotopes in serpentinites to constrain better the composition and source of fluids responsible for mantle metasomatism in diverse subduction zone settings. We obtained three main outcomes disseminated in one published journal article and two manuscripts in preparation:

Exhumed serpentinites and their tectonic significance in non-collisional orogens - Serpentinites are metamorphic rock products of fluid-mediated alteration of the mantle. They occur on the ocean floor and the core of mountain belts, resulting from continental collisions after the closure of ancient oceanic basins. However, their origin in non-collisional mountain belts like the Andes remains unclear. We studied serpentinite boulders from five river basins in the Ecuadorian northern Cordillera Real to address this conundrum. We found that rocks are composed of the high-temperature serpentine mineral, while spinel is the only original mineral preserved. River basin analysis and boron stable isotopes indicate four potential sources for the studied rocks, juxtaposed to rocks ranging in age from ~240-55 million. Bulk-rock chemistry and boron isotopes suggest that the serpentinization was triggered by crustal fluids at depths between 80-30 km in a subduction zone environment. Extensional and compressional tectonic phases have characterized the Andes over time. These tectonic scenarios enhance the extraction of rocks at deep sections of the Earth along major faults. We propose that Andean serpentinites are fragments of the Earth’s mantle sourced from ancient subduction zones and back-arc basins.

Record of deserpentinization and re-serpentinization of an exhumed slab sliver - Hydrated mantle rocks, known as serpentinites, can undergo subduction and release large amounts of fluids due to dehydration and breakdown of serpentine minerals (deserpentinization). This dehydration event plays a key role in fundamental geological processes, including chemical exchanges between the crust and the mantle, seismicity, and arc magmatism. Although the importance of this large-scale fluid release is well-known, evidence of deserpentinization is rare in the rock record. We studied the effects of deserpentinization and associated fluid circulation in exhumed, metamorphosed mantle rocks (metaperidotites) from the Raspas Complex, Ecuador. This Early Cretaceous (~130 Ma) complex records warm subduction conditions (~13.5°C/km) and has been hypothesized to represent a complete slab fragment that preserves its upper mafic and sedimentary sections. Our observations reveal that the metaperidotites underwent deserpentinization after reaching a metamorphic peak at 40-50 km depths, releasing up to 10 wt. % of water stored in the rock. However, during the ascent to shallower depths, the metaperidotites interacted with fluids that re-hydrated the rocks, producing new serpentine minerals. Boron isotopes reveal that these fluids were derived from a crustal source and were capable of altering the geochemical compositions of the metaperidotites.

Heterogeneities Within Subduction-related Serpentine Mélanges - Subduction mélanges are a chaotic mixture of blocks embedded in a matrix. The latter can comprise serpentine minerals, such as lizardite and antigorite. Despite being a rare occurrence in the geological record, serpentine mélanges exposure offers the opportunity to decipher processes in subduction zones, including chemical reactions, fluid-mediated alteration, and extraction to shallow or near-surface levels. Central America is host to multiple serpentine mélanges, which consist of a serpentine matrix mixed with blocks sourced from the downgoing oceanic crust (slab) or the overlying fore-arc sections. In Nicaragua, the Siuna Serpentinite Mélange (SSM) is a unique complex with slab and fore-arc blocks embedded in a serpentine matrix. Mineral and boron isotope analysis suggests a strong bimodality in this mélange. The northern section contains high-grade metamorphic blocks embedded in an antigorite matrix. Boron isotopes in antigorite indicate that crustal fluids affected the original mantle rock at ~45-50 km depths, producing the antigorite-rich serpentinites. In contrast, the central and southern sections of the SSM enclose low- to medium-grade metamorphic blocks within a lizardite matrix, a serpentine mineral stable at lower temperatures than antigorite, pointing to shallower depths. Boron isotopes in lizardite suggest that the mantle rocks were altered by a mixture of seawater- and crust-derived fluids. These findings imply that serpentine mélanges can carry sections from different depths of the slab-mantle interface, which can be juxtaposed during their ascent to shallower or near-surface levels.

Our main findings have also been presented to the community through talks and posters at the Goldschmidt, AGU, and GSA meetings and departmental colloquia at the Pennsylvania State University, University of Texas San Antonio, Tohoku University, University of California Santa Barbara, Georgia Institute of Technology, North Carolina State University, Universidad San Carlos de Guatemala, Universidad del Desarrollo (Chile), Universidad Nacional Andrés Bello (Chile) University of Utah, Syracuse University, and McGill University. 

The project supported the training and MS research of graduate Damian Donoso-Tapia and PI Flores, a tenure-track assistant professor belonging to an underrepresented group. Studied samples were stored at the AMNH collection, and data was uploaded to EarthChem Library.
